an4.36:1.1: At one time the Buddha was traveling along the road between Ukkaṭṭhā and Setavyā,
an4.36:1.3: Doṇa saw that the Buddha’s footprints had thousand-spoked wheels, with rims and hubs, complete in every detail.
an4.36:1.6: Surely these couldn’t be the footprints of a human being?”
an4.36:1.7: The Buddha had left the road and sat at the root of a tree cross-legged, setting his body straight, and establishing mindfulness in his presence.
an4.36:1.8: Then Doṇa, following the Buddha’s footprints, saw him sitting at the tree root—impressive and inspiring, with peaceful faculties and heart, attained to the highest self-control and serenity, like an elephant with tamed, guarded, and controlled faculties.
an4.36:1.9: He went up to the Buddha and said to him:
an4.36:2.2: “I will not be a god, brahmin.”
an4.36:3.1: “When asked whether you might be a god, centaur, spirit, or human,
an4.36:3.2: you answer that you will not be any of these.
an4.36:3.9: So what then might you be?”
an4.36:4.1: “Brahmin, if I had not given up defilements I might have become a god … a centaur … a spirit … or a human. But I have given up those defilements, cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, obliterated them so they are unable to arise in the future.
an4.36:4.3: Suppose there was a blue water lily, or a pink or white lotus. Though it sprouted and grew in the water, it would rise up above the water and stand with no water clinging to it.
an4.36:4.4: In the same way, though I was born and grew up in the world, I live having mastered the world, unsullied by the world.
an4.36:4.5: Remember me, brahmin, as a Buddha.
an4.36:5.1: I could have been reborn as a god,
an4.36:5.2: or as a centaur flying through the sky.
an4.36:5.3: I could have become a spirit,
an4.36:5.6: they’re blown away and mown down.
an4.36:6.2: to which water does not cling,
an4.36:6.3: the world doesn’t cling to me,
an4.36:6.4: and so, brahmin, I am a Buddha.”
